OVERVIEW: The Billington series consists of very deep, subaqueous soils that are permanently submerged beneath 10 to 200cm or more of tidal estuarine water in mainland coves within coastal lagoons and bays. Billington soils are formed in silty marine and estuarine deposits over buried organic material. Organic materials are mainly derived from woody fresh water environments or herbaceous tidal peat and occur within 40 through 100 cm of the soil surface. Slope ranges from 0 through 3 percent, mean annual air temperature is 10 degrees C, and mean annual precipitation is 1295 mm.

TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Coarse-silty, mixed, active, nonacid, mesic Thapto-histic Sulfiwassents

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Billington silt loam on a north facing, 1 percent concave slope in a mainland cove under 1.5 m of estuarine water. Tidal range is 24 cm.  (Colors are for moist soil).
Ase--0 to 12 cm; black (5Y 2.5/1) mucky silt loam; gray (5Y 6/1) dry; massive; very fluid; 5 percent macroalgal fragments, 14 percent organic matter; sulfurous odor; strongly saline; slightly alkaline (pH 7.7), ultra acid (pH 3.1) after 8 weeks; clear boundary.  (5 to 20 cm thick.)
Cse1--12 to 53 cm; black (5Y 2.5/1) mucky silt loam; massive; moderately fluid; 5 percent macroalgal fragments, 15 percent organic matter; sulfurous odor; strongly saline; moderately alkaline (pH 8.0), ultra acid (pH 3.2) after 8 weeks; clear boundary.
Cse2--53 to 88 cm; very dark gray (5Y 3/1) mucky silt loam; massive; moderately fluid; 12 percent organic matter; sulfurous odor; strongly saline; moderately alkaline (pH 7.9), ultra acid (pH 2.8) after 8 weeks; clear boundary.  (Combined thickness of C horizons is 25 to 80 cm thick.)
2Oaseb--88 to 98 cm; black (N 2.5/) muck, broken face and rubbed sapric material; about 10 percent herbaceous fibers, 0 percent rubbed; about 45 percent mineral content; slightly fluid; sulfurous odor; 14 percent gravel; strongly saline; neutral (pH 7.1), extremely acid (pH 3.5) after 8 weeks; abrupt boundary.  (0 to 100 cm thick.)
2Oab1--98 to 130 cm; black (10YR 2/1) muck, broken face and rubbed hemic material; about 30 percent herbaceous fiber, 3 percent rubbed; about 30 percent mineral content; slightly fluid; 1 percent wood fragments; strongly saline; neutral (pH 7.0), extremely acid (pH 4.2) after 8 weeks; clear boundary.
2Oab2--130 to 191 cm; very dark brown (10YR 2/2) muck, broken face hemic material, black (10YR 2/1) rubbed; about 35 percent herbaceous fibers, 5 percent rubbed; about 25 percent mineral content; slightly fluid; 1 percent wood fragments; strongly saline; neutral (pH 6.9), strongly acid (pH 5.2) after 8 weeks.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION: Washington County, Rhode Island; Ninigret Pond; about 3000 feet east of intersection of Route 1 and Route 1A at Ninigret Park. USGS Quonochontaug, RI topographic quadrangle, Latitude 41 degrees 22, minutes, 13 second N. and Longitude 71 degrees, 39 seconds, 4 degrees W., NAD 1983.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS: The soils are permanently submerged. One or more horizons within 50 cm have an oxidized pH of 4.0 or less. Soil has a 5:1 salinity greater than 0.6 dS/m throughout the profile. Depth to buried organic surface is 40 through 100 cm. Other lithologic discontinuities may exist below the organic surface including loess, glacial outwash, or till.
The A or Ase horizon has hue of 10YR, 5Y, 2.5Y or is neutral, value of 2.5 or 3, and chroma of 0 or 1. Texture ranges from clay through silt loam and their mucky analogs. Organic matter is 5 through 15 percent. Consistence is moderately fluid or very fluid. Reaction ranges from neutral through moderately alkaline and oxidized pH ranges from ultra acid through neutral.
The C or Cse horizon has hue of 2.5Y, 5Y or 10Y, value of 2.5 or 3, and chroma of 1 or 2. Texture is silt or silt loam and their mucky analogs. Organic matter is 5 through 18 percent. Gravel content is 0 through 5 percent. Reaction ranges from neutral through moderately alkaline and oxidized pH ranges from ultra acid through very strongly acid.
The 2Ob or 2Oseb horizon has hue of 7.5YR or 10YR or neutral, value of 2 or 2.5, and chroma of 0 through 2. Organic matter ranges from 50 through 80 percent. Wood fragment content is 0 through 5 percent. The 2Oa1 horizon has a gravel content of 0 through 14 percent. Reaction ranges from slightly acid through neutral and oxidized pH ranges from extremely acid through slightly alkaline.
Some pedons have a 3C or 4C horizon with value of 2.5Y, 10Y, 10YR, or neutral, value of 2 through 5, and chroma of 0 through 2. Texture ranges from silt loam through loamy coarse sand. It is massive or single grain.  Gravel content is 0 through 20 percent. Consistence is nonfluid. Reaction ranges from neutral through moderately alkaline and oxidized pH ranges from very strongly acid through neutral. It is 0 to 100 cm thick.

COMPETING SERIES.content:
COMPETING SERIES: There are currently no competing series.
Appoquinimink soils and Southpoint soils are in related families. Appoquinimink soils are flooded twice daily by tides. Southpoint soils have 18 through 35 percent clay in the particle size control section.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING: The Billington soils are permanently submerged with salt or brackish water in mainland coves of coastal lagoons and bays. These soils are on slightly concave through level landforms. Slope ranges from 0 through 3 percent. The soils formed in low bulk density silty estuarine sediments over freshwater or salt water organic materials in 10 through 200 cm of water.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS: These are the Anguilla, Napatree, Pishagqua, Fort Neck, and Wequetequock soils. Anguilla soils are on submerged mainland beaches and have a sandy particle-size class. Napatree soils are on submerged headlands, and submerged mainland beaches are sandy in the upper part, and lack sulfidic materials. Pishagqua soils are in low energy lagoon bottom landscapes and do not have organic horizons. The Fort Neck soils have an n-value of 0.7 or less in some horizon at a depth between 20 and 50 cm below the mineral soil surface. Wequetequock soils do not have an organic horizon within 100 cm of the soil surface.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND SATURATED HYDRAULIC CONDUCTIVITY: Subaqueous soil, peraquic soil moisture regime, moderately high or high saturated hydraulic conductivity due to low bulk density. The soil is permanently submerged with salt or brackish water.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION: Areas of this soil are used for recreational fishing and swimming. Commercial uses include shell fishing and aquaculture. Benthic fauna such as tubeworms, clams, juvenile blue crabs, scallops and juvenile finfish are associated with this soil. Eelgrass (Zostera marina) and widgeon grass (Ruppia maritima) may occur on these soils.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT: Southern Rhode Island and Connecticut. MLRA 144A and 149B. The soils of this series are not extensive (approximately 750 acres (304 hectares)).

REGIONAL OFFICE.content: SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (SSRO) RESPONSIBLE: Amherst, Massachusetts

ORIGIN.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED: Washington County, Rhode Island, 2010.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS: Diagnostic horizons and features in this pedon include:
1. Peraquic feature - positive soil water potential (permanently submerged) at the soil surface (under 1.2 m of water at the time of coring).
2. Ochric epipedon - the zone from 0 to 12 cm (Ase horizon).
3. Sulfidic materials - the zone from 0 to 88 cm (Ase and Cse horizons).
4. High n-value - the zone from 0 to 88 cm has an n-value greater than 0.7, as surmised by the very fluid and moderately fluid manner of failure (Ase and Cse horizons).
5. Sapric soil material - the zone from 88 to 191 cm (2Oabse, 2Oab1, and 2Oab2 horizons).
6. Thapto-histic - buried layer of organic material, 20 cm or more thick, within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface (2Oabse, 2Oab1, and 2Oab2 horizons).
7. Particle size control section - the zone from 25 to 88 cm (Cse1 and Cse2 horizons).
ADDITIONAL DATA:
This pedon was sampled as RI009-2009-016-NP by University of Rhode Island.  Support pedons used to develop this series include RI009-2007-007-PJ (sampled by the University of Rhode Island), RI009-2004-003-NP (sampled by the University of Rhode Island), PJ018, and GH007.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
